title: Changes to alter Powerball odds
text:
Changes to alter Powerball odds By ANDREW CAIN Richmond Times-Dispatch Richmond Times-Dispatch 
If you play Powerball, the odds are it will soon be easier to win a prize, but harder to win the jackpot. 
The odds will change because beginning Sunday, 10 numbers will be added to the field of white-ball numbers for a total of 69, and nine Powerball numbers will be removed for a total of 26. 
The changes will increase the odds of winning the jackpot from 1 in 175 million to 1 in 292 million. 
But they will improve the odds of winning any prize from 1 in 32 to 1 in 25. 
Although most of the prize levels remain the same, the $10,000 prize for matching four white-ball numbers plus the red Powerball number will jump to $50,000. 
Powerball will still cost $2 for a single play. Power Play, the $1 add-on option to Powerball, will also include a 10X multiplier anytime the advertised annuity Powerball jackpot is $150 million or less to encourage game interest at lower jackpot levels. 
“We really think Powerball players in Virginia will like these changes — and also what’s not changing,” said Paula Otto, executive director of the Virginia Lottery, noting that profits from Powerball tickets bought in Virginia will continue to go to K-12 education. 
Powerball drawings are held at 10:59 p.m. on Wednesdays and Saturdays. 
The Powerball jackpot climbed to an estimated $310 million for Wednesday’s drawing, and a ticket sold in Michigan hit the jackpot. The jackpot for Saturday’s drawing is $40 million. 
A Virginia Beach man recently claimed a Powerball ticket worth $2 million. 
Virginia’s biggest Powerball prize was claimed on Valentine’s Day in 2013. Dave and Nancy Honeywell of Fredericksburg claimed a $217 million prize.
